awd_titl_txt: Super-radiant virus-like particles as targeted contrast agents for laser-guided surgery
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI will construct the smallest reported light source with emission similar to laser light. Its brightness will be at least two orders of magnitude higher than state of the art fluorescent nanoparticles of similar size. Such a nanoscopic laser source will be valuable in guiding and assisting microscopic surgery, specifically in the brain. The PI has a well-established record of mentoring and outreach. The PI will continue these activities, e.g. mentoring a summer undergraduate student during the proposed research. 


The small size of the nanolaser will enable accessing the spaces between cells. The high brightness will enable triggering local photochemical reactions. Such a remote light source could photo stimulate a single synapse, a step towards wireless remote information exchange between the nervous system. This could also produce chemical species which selectively destroy cancer cells targeted by the nanolaser particles. The nanolaser is a unique molecular structure, its material scaffold being a virus shell. The advantage of using such a bio-enabled approach is due to the inherited molecular precision in structural organization and from self-assembly, which occurs spontaneously from simple, benign reagents.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the project was to construct the smallest reported light source with emission similar to laser light. Such a bright, nanoscopic laser source will be valuable in guiding and assisting microscopic surgery, specifically in the brain. Its concentrated light could also produce chemical species which selectively destroy cancer cells targeted by the nanolaser particles. The nanolaser is a unique molecular structure, its material scaffold being a virus shell. The advantage of using such a bio-enabled approach is due to the inherited molecular precision in structural organization and from self-assembly, which occurs spontaneously from simple, benign reagents.

Intelectual merit outcomes:

- This is the first time cooperative emission of spaced molecular fluorophores is observed at room temperatrure.  Experiments have provided insights into the mechanism of light emission, which has dynamic characteristics akin to super-radiance.

- We determined that emission dynamics is non-classical. The light emitted by virus scaffold supported fluorophores is in the form of a short, several picoseconds burst, instead of a few nanoseconds exponentially decaying uncorrelated emission, which is how uncoupled fluorophores would emit.

- We have established a set of rules to obtain non-classical intense emission. We are currently testing these rules through experiments that aim to provide further refinement. 

Broad impact:

 - Collaborations: we have established a research network including two universitties (U Carddiff, Michigan U),  and a national lab (Argonne) whose aim is to go deeper in understanding the nonclassical characteristics of light emission 

- New results have been communicated at national conferences, through invited (virtual) visits and seminars to universities, and in five peer-reviewed publications.

- Three undergraduate reserachers and one summer highschool students were partially supported from the grant to work on specific sub-projects. One of the undergraduate students is first-author on an article that first describes virus protein assembly in an aprotic organic solvent solution. The works expands the types of dyes that we can attach to the surface of a virus template  


Last Modified: 01/03/2022
Modified by: Bogdan Dragnea

Image
  • Molecular model of the brome mosaic shell with dye labeled surface and transmissionelectron micrograph of labeled particles.
    Dragnea Lab/IU
    Copyrighted
    Bogdan Dragnea
    Superradiant Viromimetic Particles
